overview: From 2025-08-24 to 2025-08-31, elizaos/eliza had 28 new PRs (23 merged), 7 new issues, and 17 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Implement Dynamic Prompting (Multi-Turn Conversations) in ElizaOS Scenarios
topIssues.author: linear
topIssues.body:
# Dynamic Prompting Implementation for ElizaOS Scenarios

## Overview

Implement **Dynamic Prompting** (multi-turn conversations) in ElizaOS scenarios to enable sophisticated testing of agent behavior through extended conversations where an LLM simulates realistic user responses.

## Problem Statement

Current ElizaOS scenarios are limited to single-turn interactions, making it impossible to test:

* Multi-step problem solving
* Context retention across conversation turns
* Clarification and follow-up question handling
* Natural conversation flow assessment
* Error recovery and correction flows

## Solution

Extend the existing scenario framework to support multi-turn conversations where:

1. **Agent** receives initial user input
2. **Agent** responds with thoughts, actions, and replies
3. **LLM Simulator** generates realistic user follow-up based on agent response
4. **Agent** continues the conversation based on simulated user input
5. Process repeats for specified number of turns or until conditions are met

## Key Requirements

### 1\. Backward Compatibility

* **100% backward compatible** - all existing scenarios must work unchanged
* Gradual adoption path for teams to enhance existing scenarios
* No breaking changes to existing APIs or CLI commands

### 2\. Core Components

#### Schema Extensions

* Extend `RunStepSchema` with optional `conversation` field
* Add new evaluation types: `conversation_length`, `conversation_flow`, `user_satisfaction`, `context_retention`
* Support conversation configuration with user simulator settings

#### User Simulator

* LLM-based response generation with persona-driven prompts
* Configurable personality, objectives, constraints, and knowledge level
* Realistic conversation progression based on agent responses

#### Conversation Manager

* Multi-turn execution orchestration
* Termination condition checking (satisfaction, solution provided, escalation needed)
* Turn-level and final evaluation support
* Conversation transcript generation

#### New Evaluators

* **Conversation Length**: Validate optimal conversation duration
* **Conversation Flow**: Detect required conversation patterns
* **User Satisfaction**: Measure user satisfaction through sentiment analysis
* **Context Retention**: Verify agent memory across conversation turns

### 3\. Configuration Examples

#### Basic Multi-Turn Conversation

```yaml
run:
  - input: "I need help with something"
    conversation:
      max_turns: 4
      user_simulator:
        persona: "polite customer with a billing question"
        objective: "find out why charged twice this month"
        temperature: 0.6
      final_evaluations:
        - type: "llm_judge"
          prompt: "Did the agent successfully help resolve the billing issue?"
          expected: "yes"
```

#### Advanced Persona-Driven Conversation

```yaml
run:
  - input: "This is ridiculous! Your product doesn't work!"
    conversation:
      max_turns: 6
      user_simulator:
        persona: "angry customer who had bad experience"
        objective: "vent frustration but eventually want help"
        style: "initially hostile, gradually becomes cooperative if handled well"
        constraints:
          - "Start with complaints and criticism"
          - "Don't accept first solution immediately"
          - "Become more cooperative if agent shows empathy"
      termination_conditions:
        - type: "user_expresses_satisfaction"
        - type: "agent_escalates_to_human"
```

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1: Core Infrastructure (Weeks 1-2)

- [ ] Schema extensions and type definitions
- [ ] User Simulator implementation
- [ ] Basic conversation flow testing

### Phase 2: Conversation Management (Weeks 3-4)

- [ ] ConversationManager class implementation
- [ ] Provider integration (LocalEnvironmentProvider, E2BEnvironmentProvider)
- [ ] Termination condition logic

### Phase 3: Evaluation System (Weeks 5-6)

- [ ] New conversation evaluators implementation
- [ ] EvaluationEngine integration
- [ ] End-to-end testing

### Phase 4: Polish and Documentation (Week 7)

- [ ] Example scenarios creation
- [ ] Documentation updates
- [ ] Performance optimizations

## Technical Specifications

### File Structure

```
packages/cli/src/commands/scenario/src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ schema.ts (extend)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ conversation-types.ts (new)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ UserSimulator.ts (new)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ConversationManager.ts (new)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ConversationEvaluators.ts (new)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ LocalEnvironmentProvider.ts (modify)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ E2BEnvironmentProvider.ts (modify)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ __tests__/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ UserSimulator.test.ts (new)
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ConversationManager.test.ts (new)
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ConversationEvaluators.test.ts (new)
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ integration/ (new tests)
```

### Key Interfaces

```typescript
interface ConversationConfig {
  max_turns: number;
  user_simulator: UserSimulatorConfig;
  termination_conditions: TerminationCondition[];
  turn_evaluations: EvaluationSchema[];
  final_evaluations: EvaluationSchema[];
}

interface UserSimulatorConfig {
  persona: string;
  objective: string;
  style?: string;
  constraints: string[];
  knowledge_level: 'beginner' | 'intermediate' | 'expert';
}
```

## Success Criteria

### Functional Requirements

- [ ] Single-turn scenarios continue to work unchanged
- [ ] Multi-turn conversations execute successfully
- [ ] User simulator generates realistic, persona-consistent responses
- [ ] Termination conditions work correctly
- [ ] All new evaluation types function properly
- [ ] Matrix testing supports conversation parameters

### Performance Requirements

- [ ] Conversation scenarios complete within reasonable time limits
- [ ] Memory usage remains within acceptable bounds
- [ ] LLM API usage is optimized and rate-limited appropriately

### Quality Requirements

- [ ] Comprehensive test coverage (unit, integration, e2e)
- [ ] Clear error handling and debugging capabilities
- [ ] Well-documented examples and migration guide

## Risk Mitigation

### Technical Risks

* **LLM API failures**: Implement retry logic and graceful degradation
* **Infinite loops**: Hard max_turns limit and timeout mechanisms
* **Memory leaks**: Turn-based cleanup and conversation archiving

### Integration Risks

* **Breaking existing scenarios**: Comprehensive backward compatibility testing
* **Performance impact**: Resource monitoring and optimization

## Dependencies

* Existing `askAgentViaApi` infrastructure
* Current evaluation engine and trajectory reconstruction
* LLM provider integration for user simulation
* Database schema (no changes required)

## Acceptance Criteria

1. **Backward Compatibility**: All existing scenarios pass without modification
2. **New Functionality**: Multi-turn conversation scenarios execute successfully
3. **Evaluation Quality**: New evaluators provide meaningful insights
4. **Performance**: No significant impact on existing scenario execution time
5. **Documentation**: Clear examples and migration path provided

topIssues.title: Fix Windows path handling in CLI agent start command tests
topIssues.author: linear
topIssues.body:
\## Description

\### Summary

Windows CI tests are failing due to incorrect path handling when running \`elizaos agent start\` with the \`--path\` flag. The file path is being malformed, resulting in doubled/concatenated paths with embedded quotes.

\### Error Details

The test command:

\`\`\`bash

elizaos agent start --remote-url http://localhost:3000 --path "D:\\a\\eliza\\eliza\\packages\\cli\\tests\\test-characters\\max.json"

\`\`\`

Results in this malformed path:

\`\`\`

D:\\a\\eliza\\eliza\\packages\\cli\\"D:\\a\\eliza\\eliza\\packages\\cli\\tests\\test-characters\\max.json"

\`\`\`

Error message:

\`\`\`

error: File not found at path: D:\\a\\eliza\\eliza\\packages\\cli\\"D:\\a\\eliza\\eliza\\packages\\cli\\tests\\test-characters\\max.json"

\`\`\`

\### Root Cause

The path resolution in \`packages/cli/src/commands/agent.ts\` (around the \`startAgent\` function) is not properly handling quoted paths on Windows. When \`path.resolve(process.cwd(), options.path)\` is called, it's incorrectly concatenating the current working directory with an already-absolute path.

\### Affected Code

\- File: \`packages/cli/dist/chunk-KKAK7OQA.js\` (compiled from source)

\- Line: Around line 3326 where \`path12.resolve(process.cwd(), options.path)\` is called

\- Source likely in: \`packages/cli/src/commands/agent.ts\` or related agent command files

\### Reproduction

Only occurs on Windows systems when running:

\`\`\`bash

bun test packages/cli/tests/create-commands.test.ts

\`\`\`

\### Proposed Fix

1\. Check if the provided path is already absolute before calling \`path.resolve()\`

2\. Handle Windows path separators and quoted paths correctly

3\. Add unit tests specifically for Windows path scenarios

\### Example Fix

\`\`\`typescript

*// Instead of:*

const filePath = path.resolve(process.cwd(), options.path);

*// Use:*

const inputPath = options.path.replace(/^"|"$/g, ''); *// Remove surrounding quotes*

const filePath = path.isAbsolute(inputPath)

? inputPath

: path.resolve(process.cwd(), inputPath);

\`\`\`

\### Priority

High - Blocking CI/CD pipeline

\### Labels

\- bug

\- windows

\- cli

\- ci-failure

topIssues.title: v2 ‚Üî v3 Benchmark Suite & Evaluation
topIssues.author: borisudovicic
topIssues.body:
**Goal**  
Create a repeatable, apples-to-apples benchmark suite that measures **accuracy, latency, and cost** for representative Eliza use cases. Results drive merit-based architectural decisions for v3 (and guardrails for future changes).

**Why now**  
We need baselines on v2 and the same tests running on v3 candidates to validate improvements in **DevEx, production readiness, tool calling, streaming, and opinionated defaults**.

## Scope

1. **Unified runner** that can execute the same test specs against:
   * **v2** (current runtime; actions/providers/event bus as implemented)
   * **v3** (tool loop prototype; declarative workflows; Drizzle/Redis stack)
2. **Scenario set** that reflects real user value and stress points:
   * **Tool calling & workflows** (multi-step, branching, error handling)
   * **Streaming path** (token + tool streaming)
   * **Multilingual** (detect ‚Üí translate ‚Üí run ‚Üí translate-back)
   * **RAG / vector** (retrieve-then-reason with pluggable vectors)
   * **Service events** (webhook/listener ‚Üí agent response)
   * **DevEx** proxy (boot ‚Üí first streamed token; commands executed)
   * **Interop** (OpenAI-compatible tool calls; MCP remote tool)
   * **Deterministic workflows** (replay under fixed seeds)
3. **Telemetry + dataset loop**
   * Trajectory logging ‚Üí dataset building ‚Üí evals (LLM-as-judge + rubric)

## Metric Definitions (source of truth)

**Latency**

* **TTFT**: time-to-first-token (ms)
* **TTFR**: time-to-final-response (ms)
* **TTS1**: time-to-first tool-call span (ms)
* **Per-step latency**: tool span durations (p50/p95)
* **Tokens/sec**: output token throughput during streaming

**Cost**

* **Prompt tokens / Completion tokens**
* **Total tokens / scenario**
* **Approx $** (using model price sheet plugged into the runner; version-pinned)

**Accuracy / Reliability**

* **Task success** (boolean via structured checks or rubric)
* **Tool-call correctness** (valid schema, correct args)
* **Groundedness** (RAG: citation presence + answer-supports-evidence score)
* **Hallucination rate** (rubric-based)
* **Replay determinism** (variance across n=5 runs with fixed seed)
* **Error rate** (non-200, exception, timeout, tool failure)

**DevEx proxies**

* **Commands to run** (from template scaffold to first streamed token)
* **Cold start to TTFT** (scripted create‚Üídev‚Üícurl path)
* **Config surface** (count of required fields; measured from template)

topPRs.title: feat: scenarios dynamic prompting + spec
topPRs.author: monilpat
topPRs.body:
# Draft Pull Request: Implement Dynamic Prompting (Multi-Turn Conversations) in ElizaOS Scenarios

## üéØ Overview

This PR implements **Dynamic Prompting** (multi-turn conversations) in ElizaOS scenarios, enabling sophisticated testing of agent behavior through extended conversations where an LLM simulates realistic user responses. This feature extends the existing single-turn scenario framework to support complex conversation flows while maintaining 100% backward compatibility.

**Ticket**: [ELIZA-669](https://linear.app/eliza-labs/issue/ELIZA-669/implement-dynamic-prompting-multi-turn-conversations-in)

## üöÄ Key Features

### ‚ú® Multi-Turn Conversation Support
- **LLM User Simulator**: Generates realistic, persona-driven user responses
- **Conversation Orchestration**: Manages multi-turn execution with termination logic
- **Turn-Level Evaluations**: Real-time assessment during conversation flow
- **Advanced Evaluators**: New conversation-specific evaluation types

### üîÑ Backward Compatibility
- **100% Compatible**: All existing single-turn scenarios work unchanged
- **Gradual Adoption**: Teams can enhance existing scenarios incrementally
- **No Breaking Changes**: Existing APIs and CLI commands remain unchanged

### üß† Intelligent Conversation Management
- **Termination Conditions**: Multiple strategies for ending conversations early
- **Context Retention**: Agent memory testing across conversation turns
- **Emotional Intelligence**: Handling complex user personas and emotional states
- **Performance Optimization**: Timeout mechanisms and resource management

## üìÅ Files Changed

### New Files
```
packages/cli/src/commands/scenario/src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ conversation-types.ts          # TypeScript interfaces for conversation components
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ UserSimulator.ts              # LLM-based user response generation
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ConversationManager.ts        # Multi-turn conversation orchestration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ConversationEvaluators.ts    # New conversation-specific evaluators
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ __tests__/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ UserSimulator.test.ts     # Unit tests for user simulator
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ConversationManager.test.ts # Unit tests for conversation manager
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ConversationEvaluators.test.ts # Unit tests for new evaluators
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ schema-conversation.test.ts # Schema validation tests
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ integration/
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ conversation-flow.test.ts # Integration tests
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ backward-compatibility.test.ts # Compatibility tests
```

### Modified Files
```
packages/cli/src/commands/scenario/src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ schema.ts                     # Extended with conversation schemas
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ LocalEnvironmentProvider.ts   # Added conversation support
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ E2BEnvironmentProvider.ts     # Added conversation support
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ EvaluationEngine.ts           # Registered new evaluators
```

### New Example Files
```
packages/cli/src/commands/scenario/examples/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ basic-conversation.yaml       # Basic multi-turn conversation
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ emotional-intelligence.yaml   # Complex persona testing
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ technical-support.yaml        # Troubleshooting conversation
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ knowledge-transfer.yaml       # Educational conversation
```

## üîß Technical Implementation

### Schema Extensions
- **ConversationConfigSchema**: Defines conversation configuration with user simulator settings
- **New Evaluation Types**: `conversation_length`, `conversation_flow`, `user_satisfaction`, `context_retention`
- **Backward Compatible**: Optional `conversation` field in existing `RunStepSchema`

### User Simulator
- **Persona-Driven**: Configurable personality, objectives, constraints, and knowledge level
- **Context-Aware**: Builds prompts based on conversation history and agent responses
- **Realistic Generation**: LLM-based response generation with behavioral constraints

### Conversation Manager
- **Multi-Turn Orchestration**: Manages conversation flow and turn execution
- **Termination Logic**: Intelligent conversation ending based on multiple conditions
- **Evaluation Integration**: Supports both turn-level and final evaluations
- **Error Handling**: Graceful handling of failures and timeouts

### New Evaluators
- **ConversationLengthEvaluator**: Validates optimal conversation duration
- **ConversationFlowEvaluator**: Detects required conversation patterns
- **UserSatisfactionEvaluator**: Measures user satisfaction through multiple methods
- **ContextRetentionEvaluator**: Verifies agent memory across conversation turns

## üìã Configuration Examples

### Basic Multi-Turn Conversation
```yaml
run:
  - input: "Hi, I need help with something"
    conversation:
      max_turns: 4
      user_simulator:
        persona: "polite customer with a billing question"
        objective: "find out why charged twice this month"
        temperature: 0.6
      final_evaluations:
        - type: "llm_judge"
          prompt: "Did the agent successfully help resolve the billing issue?"
          expected: "yes"
```

### Advanced Emotional Intelligence Testing
```yaml
run:
  - input: "This is ridiculous! Your product doesn't work!"
    conversation:
      max_turns: 6
      user_simulator:
        persona: "angry customer who had bad experience"
        objective: "vent frustration but eventually want help"
        style: "initially hostile, gradually becomes cooperative if handled well"
        constraints:
          - "Start with complaints and criticism"
          - "Become more cooperative if agent shows empathy"
      termination_conditions:
        - type: "user_expresses_satisfaction"
        - type: "agent_escalates_to_human"
      final_evaluations:
        - type: "user_satisfaction"
          satisfaction_threshold: 0.6
        - type: "conversation_flow"
          required_patterns: ["empathy_then_solution", "clarification_cycle"]
```

## üß™ Testing Strategy

### Unit Tests
- **UserSimulator**: Tests persona-driven response generation and constraint handling
- **ConversationManager**: Tests turn execution, termination logic, and error handling
- **ConversationEvaluators**: Tests all new evaluation types with various scenarios
- **Schema Validation**: Tests conversation schema validation and backward compatibility

### Integration Tests
- **Conversation Flow**: End-to-end conversation execution with realistic scenarios
- **Provider Integration**: Tests both local and cloud environment providers
- **Evaluation Integration**: Tests new evaluators with existing evaluation engine
- **Backward Compatibility**: Ensures existing scenarios work unchanged

### Performance Tests
- **Resource Usage**: Memory and CPU usage validation for long conversations
- **LLM API Optimization**: Token usage and rate limiting verification
- **Timeout Handling**: Tests timeout mechanisms and graceful degradation

## üìä Performance Impact

### Resource Usage
- **Memory**: Additional ~50MB per conversation (configurable limits)
- **CPU**: Minimal impact, primarily during LLM API calls
- **Network**: Additional LLM API calls for user simulation (optimized with caching)

### Execution Time
- **Single-Turn Scenarios**: No impact (unchanged execution path)
- **Multi-Turn Scenarios**: ~30-60 seconds per turn (configurable timeouts)
- **Matrix Testing**: Parallel execution with rate limiting

### LLM API Usage
- **User Simulation**: ~200 tokens per turn (configurable)
- **Evaluation**: ~100 tokens per evaluation (existing pattern)
- **Rate Limiting**: Built-in throttling and retry logic

## üîí Security & Reliability

### Error Handling
- **LLM API Failures**: Retry logic with exponential backoff
- **Timeout Mechanisms**: Configurable timeouts per turn and total conversation
- **Graceful Degradation**: Fallback to simpler simulation strategies
- **Resource Limits**: Memory and execution time limits to prevent runaway conversations

### Data Privacy
- **No Persistent Storage**: Conversation data not stored beyond execution
- **Transcript Export**: Optional full conversation export for debugging
- **Logging Control**: Configurable debug logging levels

## üö¶ Migration Guide

### For Existing Scenarios
**No changes required!** All existing scenarios continue to work unchanged:

```yaml
# Existing scenario - works exactly as before
run:
  - input: "Hello agent"
    evaluations:
      - type: "string_contains"
        value: "hello"
```

### For Enhanced Scenarios
Gradually add conversation features to existing scenarios:

```yaml
# Enhanced scenario - adds conversation while keeping existing evaluations
run:
  - input: "Hello agent"
    conversation:
      max_turns: 2
      user_simulator:
        persona: "friendly user"
        objective: "have brief chat"
    evaluations:  # Keep existing evaluations for compatibility
      - type: "string_contains"
        value: "hello"
```

### For New Conversation-First Scenarios
Create scenarios designed for multi-turn testing:

```yaml
# New conversation-first scenario
run:
  - input: "I have a complex problem"
    conversation:
      max_turns: 8
      user_simulator:
        persona: "confused user with technical issue"
        objective: "get step-by-step help"
      final_evaluations:
        - type: "user_satisfaction"
          satisfaction_threshold: 0.7
        - type: "conversation_length"
          optimal_turns: 5
```

## üìà Future Enhancements

### Planned Features
- **Advanced Personas**: More sophisticated user personality modeling
- **Multi-Agent Conversations**: Support for multiple agents in conversation
- **Emotional Intelligence**: Enhanced emotional state tracking and response
- **Conversation Analytics**: Advanced conversation quality metrics
- **Custom Evaluators**: Framework for custom conversation evaluators

### Performance Optimizations
- **Response Caching**: Cache common user simulation responses
- **Parallel Processing**: Concurrent evaluation execution
- **Streaming Transcripts**: Real-time conversation monitoring
- **Resource Pooling**: Shared LLM connection pools

## ‚úÖ Acceptance Criteria

### Functional Requirements
- [x] **Backward Compatibility**: All existing single-turn scenarios execute without modification
- [x] **Multi-turn Execution**: Conversation scenarios execute successfully with realistic user simulation
- [x] **User Simulation**: LLM generates persona-consistent, contextually appropriate responses
- [x] **Termination Logic**: Conversation ends appropriately based on configured conditions
- [x] **Evaluation System**: All new evaluation types provide meaningful insights
- [x] **Matrix Testing**: Matrix scenarios support conversation parameters and execute correctly
- [x] **Error Handling**: Graceful handling of LLM failures, timeouts, and edge cases

### Performance Requirements
- [x] **Execution Time**: Conversation scenarios complete within reasonable time limits (max 5 minutes for 8-turn conversation)
- [x] **Memory Usage**: Memory usage remains within acceptable bounds (max 2GB for complex scenarios)
- [x] **LLM API Usage**: Optimized token usage and rate limiting (max 1000 tokens per user simulation)
- [x] **Resource Efficiency**: No memory leaks or resource accumulation across multiple scenarios

### Quality Requirements
- [x] **Test Coverage**: Comprehensive test coverage (unit: 90%, integration: 80%, e2e: 70%)
- [x] **Error Handling**: Clear error messages and debugging capabilities
- [x] **Documentation**: Well-documented examples and migration guide
- [x] **Logging**: Comprehensive logging for debugging and monitoring
- [x] **Metrics**: Performance metrics and conversation quality measurements

## üîç Testing Instructions

### Manual Testing
1. **Backward Compatibility**: Run existing scenario suite to ensure no regressions
2. **Basic Conversation**: Test simple multi-turn conversation scenarios
3. **Complex Personas**: Test emotional intelligence and difficult user scenarios
4. **Matrix Testing**: Test conversation parameters in matrix scenarios
5. **Error Scenarios**: Test timeout, LLM failure, and resource limit scenarios

### Automated Testing
```bash
# Run all tests
bun test

# Run conversation-specific tests
bun test --grep "conversation"

# Run backward compatibility tests
bun test --grep "backward"

# Run performance tests
bun test --grep "performance"
```

## üìö Documentation

### Updated Documentation
- **Dynamic Prompting Guide**: Comprehensive implementation guide
- **Engineering Design**: Detailed technical design document
- **Configuration Examples**: Real-world scenario examples
- **Migration Guide**: Step-by-step migration instructions

### New Documentation
- **Conversation Best Practices**: Guidelines for effective conversation scenarios
- **Persona Design Guide**: How to create realistic user personas
- **Evaluation Strategies**: Advanced evaluation techniques for conversations
- **Performance Tuning**: Optimization guidelines for conversation scenarios

## ü§ù Review Checklist

### Code Quality
- [ ] **TypeScript**: All code properly typed with no `any` types
- [ ] **Error Handling**: Comprehensive error handling and edge case coverage
- [ ] **Logging**: Appropriate logging levels and debug information
- [ ] **Documentation**: Inline code documentation and JSDoc comments
- [ ] **Naming**: Clear, descriptive variable and function names

### Architecture
- [ ] **Separation of Concerns**: Clear boundaries between components
- [ ] **Dependency Management**: Proper dependency injection and loose coupling
- [ ] **Extensibility**: Framework supports future enhancements
- [ ] **Performance**: Efficient resource usage and optimization
- [ ] **Security**: Proper input validation and data handling

### Testing
- [ ] **Unit Tests**: Comprehensive unit test coverage for all components
- [ ] **Integration Tests**: End-to-end testing of conversation flows
- [ ] **Backward Compatibility**: Existing scenarios work unchanged
- [ ] **Performance Tests**: Resource usage and timeout validation
- [ ] **Error Scenarios**: Failure mode testing and recovery

### Documentation
- [ ] **User Guide**: Clear instructions for using conversation features
- [ ] **Migration Guide**: Step-by-step migration for existing scenarios
- [ ] **API Documentation**: Complete API reference for new components
- [ ] **Examples**: Comprehensive example scenarios
- [ ] **Troubleshooting**: Common issues and solutions

## üéâ Impact

This implementation significantly enhances ElizaOS scenario testing capabilities by enabling:

1. **Realistic Agent Testing**: Multi-turn conversations that test real-world interaction patterns
2. **Complex Behavior Assessment**: Evaluation of agent memory, emotional intelligence, and problem-solving
3. **Comprehensive Coverage**: Testing scenarios previously impossible with single-turn interactions
4. **Production Readiness**: Agent validation for complex customer support and assistance scenarios

The feature maintains full backward compatibility while providing a powerful new testing paradigm for sophisticated agent behavior evaluation.

topPRs.title: feat: bun build, remove tsup
topPRs.author: ChristopherTrimboli
topPRs.body:
This pull request introduces a new standardized Bun-based build system for ElizaOS packages, replacing the previous use of `tsup` and related tooling. It adds reusable build utilities, custom build scripts for `@elizaos/api-client` and `@elizaos/cli`, and updates package scripts and dependencies to leverage these changes. Additionally, there are targeted fixes and improvements to messaging service payloads, environment setup, and process management.

**Build System Modernization**

* Added `build-utils.ts` with reusable Bun build utilities for cleaning, building, copying assets, and generating TypeScript declarations, enabling consistent builds across packages.
* Replaced `tsup` with Bun-based scripts in `@elizaos/api-client` and `@elizaos/cli`, including custom build scripts (`build.ts`) and removal of `tsup.config.ts`. Updated package scripts to use Bun for build, watch, and clean operations. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-c64f755bd238752518269ba933743007c8b7c2b3db7b2663c3cfd8eee3e66ee1R1-R59) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-fd8bcdbf9ab496c42cc8f5a68cbb792d0cd44d138d9f35e6ef960ac6a7b97168L10-R16) [[3]](diffhunk://#diff-fd8bcdbf9ab496c42cc8f5a68cbb792d0cd44d138d9f35e6ef960ac6a7b97168L24) [[4]](diffhunk://#diff-1870665c82b8dca54d6e63c49dfa1077b64d4b37bc32f66610ff543ad7f00dcbL1-L18) [[5]](diffhunk://#diff-38a7bfc3de9135d0af986757713f0fc589a906dd9be2f715932e303ae8bc7e4cR1-R82) [[6]](diffhunk://#diff-6e2e2a1851648938b325ba84de634407a4e69a644ea61102df15ca4a8a7a9758L40-R44) [[7]](diffhunk://#diff-6e2e2a1851648938b325ba84de634407a4e69a644ea61102df15ca4a8a7a9758R59) [[8]](diffhunk://#diff-6e2e2a1851648938b325ba84de634407a4e69a644ea61102df15ca4a8a7a9758L71-L75)
* Updated monorepo-level build and clean scripts in `package.json` to filter out certain packages, remove `tsup`, and improve cache handling for faster, more reliable builds. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-7ae45ad102eab3b6d7e7896acd08c427a9b25b346470d7bc6507b6481575d519L11-R19) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-7ae45ad102eab3b6d7e7896acd08c427a9b25b346470d7bc6507b6481575d519L52)

**Messaging Service Improvements**

* Refactored payload construction for channel creation methods in `MessagingService` to match server expectations, including proper handling of metadata, participant IDs, and DM channel parameters.
* Fixed type handling in participant filtering logic for channel updates.

**TypeScript Declaration Generation**

* Enabled TypeScript declaration file (`.d.ts`) generation via Bun build scripts and updated `tsconfig.build.json` to include `"declaration": true`. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-c64f755bd238752518269ba933743007c8b7c2b3db7b2663c3cfd8eee3e66ee1R1-R59) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-38a7bfc3de9135d0af986757713f0fc589a906dd9be2f715932e303ae8bc7e4cR1-R82) [[3]](diffhunk://#diff-c4d3cf5a942b53c98c3bd2b84fbc766b044cfa190d26f1a249dd7357486a7a5aL4-R5)

**Process and Environment Management**

* Improved environment variable setup in CLI server manager to filter out undefined values and ensure proper module resolution.
* Updated server process termination logic to ensure graceful shutdown and state cleanup.
* Minor fix to plugin upgrade progress event handling for more robust logging.
* Removed unused `writeFileSync` import in CLI plugin environment variable utilities.

completedItems.title: improve summary
fix: Remove duplicate actionNames block from message handler template
completedItems.body: The actionNames block was appearing twice in the messageHandlerTemplate: once correctly inside the <providers> section and once redundantly after it. This PR removes the duplicated block after the </providers> tag to streamline the template

completedItems.title: fix: core types output
completedItems.body:
## üîß Fix: Type Export Issues in @elizaos/core Package

### Problem
The deployed version of `@elizaos/core` on NPM was experiencing type export failures, causing TypeScript compilation errors when the package was used outside the monorepo.
